awd_titl_txt: Conference: Gordon Research Conference on Batteries-Ventura
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide partial support for the 2024 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Batteries, to be held in Ventura, CA on February 25-March 1, 2024. The GRC will provide significant professional development activities for graduate students and post doctoral research fellows in the area of electrochemical energy storage. The GRC will also stimulate new advances in batteries for renewable energy storage through interaction of scientists and engineers who are both new and established in this field.

The technical challenges of understanding and improving current electrochemical energy storage systems, which include batteries, require a collaborative effort from researchers in many disciplines. There are still many fundamental gaps in understanding the atomic- and molecular-level processes that determine and govern the function, operation, performance limitations, and failure of battery systems. Fundamental knowledge is critically needed to uncover the underlying principles that control these complex and interrelated processes. With this underpinning knowledge, wholly new concepts in materials design can be developed for producing electrodes, electrolytes, and battery cells that are capable of storing higher energy densities and have long cycle lifetimes, at lower cost. The conference will cover topics related to solid state batteries, next generation batteries, advanced characterization, battery recycling, and policy and techno- economics. The theme of the GRC on batteries highlights theory, materials synthesis, and engineering concepts under the umbrella of the conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This funding supported the registration of approximately 20 graduate students and postdoctoral fellows for the Battery Gordon Conference. The conference addressed a variety of topics related to electrochemical energy storage, including battery recycling, manufacturing, and next-generation battery technologies.

The intellectual merit of the conference stemmed from access to unpublished research presented by scientists from around the world. It showcased cutting-edge experimental techniques and advancements in battery science.

The conference provided a unique platform for students to deepen their understanding of the rapidly evolving field of battery technology. Exposure to the latest advancements allowed them to stay informed about industry trends, emerging research areas, and practical applications. By attending technical sessions and engaging with experts, students gained insights that could directly enhance their own research and career development.

The conference was preceded by a seminar where students had the opportunity to deliver oral presentations of their research. Additionally, the conference featured student poster sessions on multiple evenings, fostering engagement and collaboration.

This funding played a crucial role in workforce development and networking for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. The seminar included a career panel, where participants gained insights into career opportunities in government, industry, and academia. The diverse audience further enabled attendees to network directly, receive valuable feedback on their work, and build professional connections.

 


Last Modified: 01/07/2025
Modified by: Kelsey B Hatzell
